awd_titl_txt: SFS Capacity Building in Security of Software Defined Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Software defined networking (SDN) is a relatively new technology expected to have wide use in the Internet due to its technical flexibility and potential for cost-savings. However, given the rapid adoption of SDN technologies, security concerns have emerged. The proposed project from the University of Texas at Dallas (UT Dallas) brings together a team of faculty with expertise in computer networks and SDN, as well as faculty with expertise in cybersecurity, to build a comprehensive curriculum to address the various security aspects of SDN. The goal is to train a skilled workforce in SDN technology and its security. Students graduating from this program will acquire the necessary skills to build, deploy, and operate an SDN based networks in academia, industry and the government. The course modules and set of capstone projects in SDN security will be made available to academia and industry so that security of this technology keeps pace with wide-spread adoption.

The proposed project aims to design a number of course modules; develop several capstone projects; and build a laboratory setup for students to implement prototype systems to test their solutions to the security issues in the capstone projects. Topics covered in the educational materials will include: cybersecurity including system security, network security, data and application security, security of cyber physical systems, and language based security, as well as in next generation computer networks, network management and SDN. The products will be incorporated into several existing graduate-level cybersecurity courses at UT Dallas, and be made available to other institutions that want to expand their curriculum to cover SDN technologies. Further, the project will involve undergraduate students in SDN research activities, and serve as a recruitment tool for students interested in furthering their education in the security of emerging technologies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The main focus of this project is to build instructional curriculum on security of software defined networks (SDNs). The resulting lecture presentations and laboratory exercises could be used (typically) in graduate level courses to introduce SDN security concepts to the students and enable them gains practical hands on experience in designing, developing and deploying solutions to various SDN security challenges that are relevant to real life use scenarios. This project resulted in a large and exhaustive set of learning modules on SDN security. The total count of slides developed is about 400. Most of these slides are annotated with explanations of the material on the slides. The main idea behind the set of modules is to comprehensively discuss the various security challenges in SDN, survey the possible and proposed solution approaches, and evaluate those approaches.  Development of modules cover close to 80 topics. These topics are based on a collection of close to 150 scientific papers from conferences and journals.

This project also resulted in an SDN Security Laboratory Manual booklet that includes eight multi-step laboratory exercises on various security vulnerabilities of SDN deployments. The booklet also includes three chapters to provide a crash course on SDN and its relevant technologies including virtualization, mininet, ONOS controller, OpenvSwitch, docker, and other relevant technologies. The lab booklet also includes an instructor manual part that includes sample solutions to the lab exercises that can be used by instructors. The booklet includes SDN security labs on (1) unauthorized access by compromised controllers, (2) unauthorized access by unauthorized applications, (3) DDoS attack detection and mitigation, (4) network configuration issues, (5) ARP spoofing attack mitigation, (6) moving target defense, (7) ML-based network intrusion detection, and (8) closed loop automation. Both the lecture material and lab exercises are available to educations based on request to the PIs.

Modified by: Kamil Sarac
